title: 109_hr3492
content: The "Consumer Credit Card Protection Act of 2005" prohibits universal defaults on credit card accounts. The Truth in Lending Act now prohibits creditors from using adverse information to increase interest rates on credit card accounts, unless directly related to the consumer's actions. The Truth in Lending Act prohibits creditors from using adverse information to increase interest rates on credit card accounts, unless unrelated to the consumer's actions. Credit card issuers must clearly inform consumers about this limitation in disclosures or statements. SEC. 3. BOX DISCLOSURE OF PAYMENT PERIOD FOR MINIMUM PAYMENTS ON CREDIT CARD BALANCE. Section 127(b) of the Truth in Lending Act is amended to include new requirements for minimum payment terms on credit card balances. This includes clear and conspicuous repayment information in a tabular format, showing the required minimum monthly payment as a dollar figure and percentage of the outstanding balance, along with the estimated number of months to pay off the balance. The amendment to Section 127(b) of the Truth in Lending Act introduces new requirements for minimum payment terms on credit card balances. This includes providing clear and concise repayment information in a tabular format, indicating the required minimum monthly payment as a dollar amount and percentage of the outstanding balance, along with an estimate of the number of months needed to pay off the balance. The creditor must apply the applicable annual percentage rate of interest for disclosures, considering different rates for various outstanding balance portions, regardless of fixed or variable rates. The creditor must apply the annual percentage rate of interest for disclosures, whether fixed or variable, including temporary or introductory rates that will change based on an index or formula for subsequent adjustments. The creditor must consider the annual percentage rate of interest, including temporary or introductory rates, based on an index or formula for subsequent adjustments. SEC. 4. ADVANCED NOTICE REQUIRED BEFORE INCREASING RATES OR FEES ON CREDIT CARD ACCOUNTS. Section 127 of the Truth in Lending Act is amended to require advance notice of any increase in interest rates or fees on credit card accounts. The notice must be provided at least 30 days before the change takes effect. The Truth in Lending Act now requires advance notice of any increase in interest rates on credit card accounts, with changes taking effect either 30 or 60 days after the obligor receives specific notice. The Truth in Lending Act mandates advance notice of interest rate increases on credit card accounts, with changes effective 30 or 60 days after the obligor receives specific notice. Additionally, no fees can be imposed on the account before the end of a 30-day period after receiving notice of the fee. The Truth in Lending Act requires advance notice of interest rate increases on credit card accounts, with changes taking effect 30 or 60 days after the obligor receives specific notice. No fees can be imposed on the account before the end of a 30-day period after receiving notice of the fee, which must be sent separately from any statement or other notice without advertising or disclosures. The notice must explain how, when, and why a fee will be imposed on the account, along with options for addressing the fee and preventing future fees.
